channel.title: Golang Weekly
channel.description: A weekly newsletter about the Go programming language

item.title: ã€Stop worrying about Go's error handling syntaxã€‘ä¸å†æ‹…å¿ƒGOçš„é”™è¯¯å¤„ç†è¯­æ³•
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹556 â€” June 4, 2025

UnsubÂ Â |Â Â WebÂ Version

ğŸ–Šï¸ I was meant to be travelling this week. My plans changed, but Iâ€™d already planned for a shorter issue, so itâ€™s a quicker one this time. Back to full service next week!
__
Peter Cooper, your editor

Go Weekly

â€œFor the foreseeable future, the Go team will stop pursuing syntactic language changes for error handling. We will also close all open and incoming proposals that concern themselves primarily with the syntax of error handling, without further investigation.â€

___
Robert Griesemer and the Go team

[ On | No ] Syntactic Support for Error Handling â€” The topic of handling errors in Go, and if itâ€™s possible to improve the syntax around doing so, has been raised many times over the years, but sometimes itâ€™s worth drawing a line under things and to focus elsewhere. Robert explains the matter, some of the proposals made over the years, and the benefits of maintaining the statusÂ quo.

Robert Griesemer

The Guide to In-House Vs Managed Kubernetes-As-A-Service â€” Struggling with the â€œbuild vs. buyâ€ decision when it comes to Kubernetes infrastructure management? You're not alone! Download the guide to discover the pros and cons of each approach as we break down the associated costs, risks & ROI. Get itÂ today!

Fairwinds sponsor

Pure vs. Impure Iterators in Go â€” Go 1.23 introduced custom iterators, but the standard â€˜single-useâ€™ vs. not classification can be confusing. This post proposes a clearer pure vs. impure distinction, with concrete examples and performanceÂ insights.

Julien Cretel

IN BRIEF:

  • Even if you don't need it, this JavaScript Developer's Guide to Go is a primer that might suit someone on yourÂ team.

  • The latest annual Stack Overflow survey is now open â€“ check it out if you want to increase Go's representation in the resultsÂ :-)

Three Cool slog.Logger Tricks â€” Make slog.Logger sing with a few smart, composable loggingÂ patterns.

Joeson Huang

Simpler Backoff â€” Exponential backoff algorithms can be complex and difficult to reason about, or you can use a lookup table to make itÂ trivial.

Josh Bleecher Snyder

ğŸ“„ The Perils of Pointers in the Land of the Zero-Sized Type â€“ Pointergeist is definitely my favorite word of theÂ day. Fillmore Labs

ğŸ“º Making a Game in Go with No Experience â€“ Interesting to see someone totally new to Go leap in and use Ebitengine to produce resultsÂ quickly. Goodgis

ğŸ“„ Let's Write a JSON Parser from Scratch Sushant Dhiman

ğŸ“„ Cross-Compiling C and Go via cgo with Bazel Uros Popovic

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

Bob 0.35: SQL Query Builder and ORM/Factory Generator â€” Though v0.36 and v0.37 have come out in just the past few days, v0.35 was a big milestone for Bob as it enabled the creation of code for SELECT, INSERT, UPDATE and DELETE queries for Postgres, MySQL and SQLite. Numerous other improvements demand you give it another look too, though â€“ some examplesÂ here.

Stephen Afam-Osemene

ğŸ’¡ You might also find Bob vs GORM a usefulÂ comparison (there are also comparisons with Ent, SQLBoiler, and Jet over on theÂ left).

franz-go: A Complete Apache Kafka Client Library â€” A library that â€œaims to provide every Kafka feature from Apache Kafka v0.8.0 onwardâ€ and certainly has a strikingÂ featureset.

Travis Bischel

httpgrace: A net/http Wrapper with Graceful Shutdown â€” Rather than call http.ListenAndServe, the idea is you can call httpgrace.ListenAndServe and get graceful shutdown bakedÂ in.

Enrico Candino

  • MCP Go 0.31 â€“ An implementation of the Model Context ProtocolÂ (MCP).

  • Revive 1.10 â€“ Fast, configurable, extensible, flexible linter forÂ Go.

  • dae 1.0 â€“ High-performance eBPF-based transparentÂ proxy.

  • FrankenPHP 1.7 â€“ Modern Go-powered PHP appÂ server.

  • Air 1.62 â€“ Live reload for Go apps.

  • pdfcpu 0.11 â€“ Go PDFÂ processor.

â­ A golden oldie..

go-binsize-treemap: Render a Visualization of Go Executable Space Usage â€” Easier to look at than explain in writing! Itâ€™s a tool that generates an SVG treemap of how the space inside a Go-built executable is used. Even when it's not useful, it's fun to lookÂ at.

Nikolay Dubina

Julien Cretel

ğŸ“„ Fillmore Labs

item.title: ã€Go 1.25's JSON evolutionã€‘èµ°1.25çš„Json Evolution
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹559 â€” June 25, 2025

UnsubÂ Â |Â Â WebÂ Version

Go Weekly

JSON Evolution in Go: From V1 to V2 â€” A good look into the practicalities of using the JSON v2 package which lands in Go 1.25 (final release due in August) with new field tags, updated marshal defaults, streaming APIs, and other niceties. Highlights include joined custom marshalers and up to 10Ã— fasterÂ unmarshaling.

Anton Zhiyanov

Finding Performance Problems by Diffing Two Go Profiles â€” Goâ€™s pprof profiling tool can show the difference between two profiles to highlight where one run slowed down. Dolt used it to pinpoint a wrongly hard-coded parameter that forced expensive system-tableÂ generation.

Zach Musgrave (DoltHub)

Fullstack without Frameworks â€” Maximiliano Firtman combines vanilla JavaScript and Go to create high-performance apps from scratch. Follow along in this video course and learn more about web components, dynamic client-side routing, authentication, logging and everything inÂ between.

Frontend Masters sponsor

Cloud66's Go Stack in 2025 â€” One Go team shares a little background to its packages of choice, covering configuration management, CLI framework, HTTP framework, ORM, and dependency injection and lifecycleÂ management.

Khash Sajadi

How to Store Go Pointers from (Go) Assembly â€” Goâ€™s assembler is an interesting, deep part of the Go toolchain for writing low-level routines and interfacing directly with Goâ€™s runtime. Few Go developers need to go this deep, but itâ€™s handy to have such aÂ writeup.

Francesco

'Go Should Be More Opinionated' â€” â€œGo should be more opinionated about the application layout.â€ This is just one developerâ€™s opinion, but app layout and architecture posts are always popular in thisÂ newsletter.

Elton Minetto

Eliminating Dead Code in Go Projects â€” Back in 2023, the Go team released a deadcode tool to identify unreachableÂ code.

Matheus Mina

ğŸ“„ How and Why Grab Rewrote a Go Microservice in Rust â€“ Not necessarily a happy ending for gophers, but itâ€™s interesting to hear about theirÂ experience. Grab Engineering

ğŸ“„ Comparing Rust, JavaScript and Go for Authoring WASM Components Obelisk

ğŸ“„ Calling Go from Elixir with a CNode (in Crystal!) â€“ â€œWe needed to connect a new Elixir Phoenix LiveView app to an existing Go backend. This is how we didÂ it.â€ Karl Matthias

ğŸ“„ Don't Mock the Database: Data Fixtures are Parallel Safe and Fast Brandur Leach (Crunchy Data)

ğŸ“„ Compressing for the Browser in Go â€“ Comparing gzip, Brotli and zstdÂ compression. Krzysztof Kowalczyk

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

Charm Fang: A CLI Starter Kit for Cobra Apps â€” A new Charm release is always worth a look â€“ they create fantastic, well-thought-out libraries. Fang is a layer on top of Cobra, adding fancy output/errors, man pages, completions, and other out-of-the-box UX improvements for CLI apps. Itâ€™s new so the docs are limited for now, but this example code will point you in the rightÂ direction.

Charm

Unregistry: Push Docker Images Directly to Remote Servers â€” A lightweight container image registry that stores and serves images directly from your Docker daemonâ€™s storage. Even one of Dockerâ€™s creators said they thought it wasÂ cool.

Pasha Sviderski

Open Source Outbound Webhooks Infrastructure â€” Built in Go. Features: Event Destinations, retries, topic subscription, OpenTelemetry, failure alerts, userÂ portal.

Outpost sponsor

makefile-graph: Turn a Makefile into a Graph â€” Usable as both a library and CLI tool, this parses Makefiles and generates graphs representing the relationships between the fileâ€™s targets (to then be rendered by Graphviz dot).

Marin Atanasov Nikolov

BillionMail 3.0: Open Source Email Marketing Platform â€” A Go-powered mail server and newsletter/email sending service. AGPL licensed. GitHubÂ repo.

aaPanel

ğŸ’¡ Listmonk is another Go-powered option to consider in thisÂ space.

  • quic-go 0.53 â€“ "A massive overhaul" for the pure Go QUICÂ implementation.

  • gore 0.6.1 â€“ Yet another Go REPL for GoÂ 1.24+.

  • go-redis 9.11 â€“ Official Go Redis clientÂ library.

  • go-github 73.0 â€“ GitHub v3 API clientÂ library.

  • fx 37.0 â€“ Powerful terminal JSONÂ viewer.

ğŸ‘€ New and Quirky Projects

A few projects have appeared on our radar recently which aren't necessarily things you'd introduce into your own apps but which you might find interesting or fun:

  • ğŸ•¹ï¸ SSHTron (above) is a multiplayer Tron-style 'lightcycle' game that runs over SSH. You can run it for yourself or try ssh sshtron.zachlatta.com and see if anyone else isÂ around..

  • Mochi is a small embeddable language targeting AI and agentic use-cases that compiles to bytecode that runs on a VM built in Go.

  • Dizer is a custom DNS server written in Go. Its homepage even breaks down most of the source code so you can more easily understand how itÂ works.

  • GUItignore is a Web-based tool for creating .gitignore files covering one or more dev ecosystems of your choice, includingÂ Go.

  • Parser is a new Go library for filtering slices of structs using an SQL-like queryÂ language. We hope to feature this again as it progresses, it looksÂ cool.

  • lazycontainer is a new BubbleTea-powered 'fancy terminal UI' for Apple Containers, as currently in macOS TahoeÂ Beta.

  • AGL (AnotherGoLang) is a Go-esque language that compiles to Go.

ã€‘
>>>>>>>>>

- æ–°çš„ Charm å§‹ç»ˆå€¼å¾—ä¸€è¯• - ä»–ä»¬åˆ›é€ å‡ºäº†å¥‡å¦™çš„ï¼Œè‰¯å¥½çš„å¤–è§‚å›¾ä¹¦é¦†ã€‚æ–¹æ˜¯ cobra ï¼Œæ·»åŠ å¹»æƒ³çš„è¾“å‡º/é”™è¯¯ï¼Œç”·å­é¡µé¢ï¼Œå®Œæ•´ä»¥åŠå…¶ä»–åŠå…¶ä»–cli apps for cli for cli for cli appsã€‚å®ƒæ˜¯æ–°çš„ï¼Œå› æ­¤æ–‡æ¡£ç°åœ¨å—åˆ°é™åˆ¶ï¼Œä½†æ˜¯æ­¤ç¤ºä¾‹ä»£ç å°†æŒ‡å‘æ­£ç¡®çš„æ–¹å‘ã€‚

- è½»å·§çš„å®¹å™¨å›¾åƒæ³¨å†Œè¡¨ï¼Œè¯¥æ³¨å†Œè¡¨å¯ç›´æ¥ä»Docker Daemonçš„å­˜å‚¨ä¸­å­˜å‚¨å’Œæä¾›å›¾åƒã€‚ç”šè‡³Dockerçš„åˆ›ä½œè€…ä¸­çš„ä¸€ä½éƒ½è¯´ä»–ä»¬è®¤ä¸ºè¿™å¾ˆé…·ã€‚

pasha sviderski

- å†…ç½®ã€‚åŠŸèƒ½ï¼šäº‹ä»¶ç›®çš„åœ°ï¼Œæ£€ç´¢ï¼Œä¸»é¢˜è®¢é˜…ï¼ŒOpenTelemetryï¼Œæ•…éšœè­¦æŠ¥ï¼Œç”¨æˆ·é—¨æˆ·ã€‚

Marin Atanasov Nikolov

- ä¸€å°Go-Power Mail Serverå’ŒNewsletlets/Email Sending Serviceã€‚ AGPLè®¸å¯ã€‚ github repoã€‚

item.title: ã€Dealing with race conditionsã€‘å¤„ç†ç§æ—æ¡ä»¶
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹558 â€” June 18, 2025

UnsubÂ Â |Â Â WebÂ Version

Go Weekly

Dealing with Race Conditions in Go â€” Anton has written some fantastic posts about concurrency in Go and this latest outing takes us deep into race conditions, including uncovering check-thenâ€‘set hazards, compareâ€‘andâ€‘set retries, idempotent Close patterns, TryLock caveats and a channelâ€‘based â€œsharedâ€‘nothingâ€ processor.

Anton Zhiyanov

Complete Go for Professional Developers â€” Craft production-grade APIs with Go, the language trusted by tech giants! Connect to Postgres, implement auth, and write tests that matter. Taught by a Twitch ML engineer who solves real problems with GoÂ daily.

Frontend Masters sponsor

IN BRIEF:

  • ğŸ“Š The SQLite Drivers 25.06 Benchmarks Game presents the results of benchmarking mattn/go-sqlite3, modernc/sqlite, and ncruces/go-sqlite3, libraries which all take different approaches to interfacing with SQLite.

  • ğŸ‡¬ğŸ‡§ GopherCon UK 2025 takes place this August and the schedule is now live.

  • ğŸ•¹ï¸ NebuLeet is a new game on Steam that's built in Go using Ebitengine â€“ it has a free demoÂ available.

  • ğŸ® Talking of games, the Ebitengine Game Jam has just started â€“ you get two weeks (well, eleven days as of now) to build and submit aÂ game.

OpenTelemetry for Go: Measuring the Overhead â€” If your app is logging everything it does, thatâ€™s another job that can eat into the resources available to it. But by how much? Nikolay runs a benchmark here to findÂ out.

Nikolay Sivko

ğŸ“„ Why I Made Peace With Goâ€™s Date Formatting Preslav Rachev

ğŸ“º Statically and Dynamically Linked Go Binaries package main

ğŸ“„ Things You Never Wanted To Know About Go Interfaces Miguel Young de la Sota

ğŸ“„ Writing a Load Balancer From Scratch in 250 Lines of Code Sushant Dhiman

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

TinyGo 0.38.0: Now with (Initial) Multicore Support â€” The Go compiler for â€˜small placesâ€™ (mostly embedded systems and WebAssembly targets) gets its first multicore support initially targeting the RP2040. Thereâ€™s also USB Mass Storage Device support for certain processors, and a new experimental GC for WASM toÂ try.

Ron Evans

â™Ÿï¸Â Introducing Chess V2: A New Chess Library â€” A library that implements the main logic of chess, including move generation, position parsing, and support for Portable Game Notation. Thereâ€™s even an example Go program to let you play a (unskilled) game against it. GitHubÂ repo.

Brigham Skarda

  • go-echarts 2.6 â€“ Charting and data visualization library that uses ApacheÂ ECharts. You can see examples in theÂ docs.

  • VHS 0.10 â€“ CLI 'home video recorder'. "Write terminal GIFs as code for integration testing and demoing your CLIÂ tools."

  • MCP-Go 0.32 â€“ An implementation of the Model Context ProtocolÂ (MCP).

  • Netpoll 0.7.1 â€“ High-perf non-blocking I/O networking framework focused on RPCÂ scenarios.

  • lakeFS 1.60 â€“ Git-like data version control for your dataÂ lake.

  • Delve 1.25 â€“ Popular debugging tool for GoÂ code.

  • Mockery 3.4 â€“ Mock codeÂ autogenerator.

ğŸ“°Â Classifieds

ğŸ§  Discern is hiring a senior full-stack Go/React dev to help automate entity compliance (US/LATAM). Join us:Â https://wellfound.com/l/2zxcz1

ğŸ˜ PostgreSQL user? Check out our sister newsletter, Postgres Weekly, for the latest Postgres news eachÂ Thursday.

âœ‚ï¸Â  Deep cuts from the queue

As it's a quieter week than usual, we've gone back to look through our ever-growing queue of items which haven't yet made it into the newsletter for one reason or another. Here are some of the things that jumped out:

  • Glance (above) is a Go-powered personal information dashboard/portal where you can bring together RSS feeds, Reddit posts, Hacker News posts, YouTube channel updates, stock prices, andÂ more.

  • Eli Bendersky demonstrates how to build static binaries with Go on Linux, including linking C into Go binaries and usingÂ Zig.

  • Alejandro SÃ¡ez MorollÃ³n explains how to package Go apps for Red Hat EnterpriseÂ Linux.

  • David Singleton posts about writing a simple BASIC to Go transpiler.

  • ğŸµ NOSTALGIA is a 90s style demoscene demo written in Go and using Ebitengine. You can â–¶ï¸Â watch a video sampleÂ here.

  • Boxes and Glue is a TeX-inspired PDF typesettingÂ library.

  • Glojure is a Clojure interpreter, hosted onÂ Go.

ã€‘
>>>>>>>>>

  • ğŸ‡¬ğŸ‡§

  • ğŸ•¹ï¸

opentelemetry for Goï¼šæµ‹é‡å¼€é”€ - å¦‚æœæ‚¨çš„åº”ç”¨ç¨‹åºæ­£åœ¨è®°å½•æ‰€æœ‰æ“ä½œï¼Œé‚£æ˜¯å¦ä¸€ä¸ªå¯ä»¥åœ¨å¯ç”¨çš„èµ„æºä¸­åƒæ‰çš„å·¥ä½œã€‚ä½†æ˜¯ï¼Œå°¼å¤æ‹‰ï¼ˆNikolayï¼‰åœ¨è¿™é‡Œè¿è¡Œäº†å¤šå°‘ï¼Ÿ

Nikolay Sivko

item.title: ã€Go 1.25 Release Candidate 1 releasedã€‘é€‰æ‹©1.25é‡Šæ”¾å€™é€‰äºº1é‡Šæ”¾
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹557 â€” June 11, 2025

UnsubÂ Â |Â Â WebÂ Version

Go Weekly

Go 1.25 Release Candidate 1 â€” The final release of Go 1.25 isnâ€™t till August, but the Go team is confident enough to issue the first RC now. The only language change is the removal of the notion of core types as explained by Robert Griesemer recently. Thereâ€™s plenty going on behind the scenes, though, like the new experimental garbage collector and changes to both GOMAXPROCS and the generation of debuggingÂ information.

The Go Team

The Draft Go 1.25 Release Notes â€” Go 1.25 RC1 has landed today but the release notes for the final release are already being worked on in advance and make for a handy reference to what you canÂ expect.

The Go Team

Complete Go for Professional Developers â€” Craft production-grade APIs with Go, the language trusted by tech giants! Connect to Postgres, implement auth, and write tests that matter. Taught by a Twitch ML engineer who solves real problems with GoÂ daily.

Frontend Masters sponsor

Why I'm Excited About Go for Agents â€” If you view agents as (mostly) stateless tasks running in a loop, then Goâ€™s concurrency model and use of Context make the language nearly perfect for developing them. Plus, Goâ€™s excellent profiling story means youâ€™ll be able to chase down any memory or threadÂ leaks.

Alexander Belanger (Hatchet)

IN BRIEF:

  • Go 1.24.4 and 1.23.1 have beenÂ released.
